description: September 14, 2020: With Bulletin N. 262, the Italian Ministry of Health announced that the Italian Minister of Health, Roberto Speranza, has attended the 70th session of the WHO Regional Committee for Europe (RC70), organised by the WHO Regional Office for Europe, on September 14 and 15, 2020. Representatives of 53 countries in the WHO European Region have attended. Representatives of WHO partners such as United Nations agencies and other intergovernmental organisations and regional networks, were also present. Non-State actors (NSAs) in official relations with WHO and regional NSAs accredited by the Regional Committee, have followed the webstream and had the opportunity to submit video and written statements in advance. The key health issues and future plans have been discussed, particularly on themes regarding the response to the COVID-19 pandemic and lessons learned from the pandemic, both globally and regionally.

description: the Flemish Community in Belgium on the 30th of March 2020launched a dedicated webpage on Covid-19 on www.gezondheidenwetenschap.be. description:
The Belgium-Luxembourg hub, which will be launched in October 2021, will gather a network of more than 100 experienced fact-checkers, employees from media organisations (including RFL and Agence France-Presse), disinformation analysts, media literacy organisations.
The aim of the initiative is to detect, analyse and expose emerging harmful disinformation campaigns and to increase media literacy in five languages (Dutch, French, English, German, Luxembourgish).

From May 25th, practical tests for the B, BE, and G categories will be permitted again. However, certain measures will become mandatory such as wearing a face mask in the car during lessons or the practical exams. Centers will also disinfect the car each time. People who are feeling ill are recommended to make another appointment.

description:
In Belgium, preschools reopen from June 2nd and primary schools reopen from June 8th.
The communities decide whether or not to reopen secondary schools, but are only allowed to reopen these schools for a few days. UPDATE: As of June 2nd, preschools in Belgium reopen (masks and social distancing not required).
As of June 8th, primary schools reopen (masks advised for staff, social distancing required for staff and parents).

In regard to the reopening of secondary schools, the Communities may decide to allow more pupils to return to school but only for a few days.

For all types of education, the following conditions apply:
The wearing of masks is highly recommended for pupils and school staff.
- Hygiene measures (frequent hand washing, etc.) remain essential for everyone.
- Classrooms, corridors and staffrooms must be kept well ventilated at all times.
- Outdoor lessons and activities should be prioritised where possible.
- Every school must have an emergency plan for dealing with an outbreak.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)
institution_status: Primary Schools closed/locked down

description: Flemish-speaking: Safety measures have been tightened in all Flemish-speaking schools. Face masks are made compulsory for pupils older than 12 in the schoolyard unless they can keep a distance. Secondary schools can provide distance learning for second and third grades (students from 14 to 18 years old) if necessary, on the condition that all pupils can be reached effectively. In universities, 20 percent of students will be allowed to attend on-site, while the rest must follow classes remotely. Half of first-year students can attend on-site. However, almost all higher education institutions have switched to digital classes, even though they are not obliged to do so by the Flemish government. French-speaking: Classes in secondary schools will be done virtually from October 28 on; no pupils will be allowed on site. All university courses are now virtual, including for first-year students. There will no longer be any on-site presence until November 19. In Flanders, safety measures have been tightened; secondary schools can provide distance learning for second and third grades (students from 14 to 18 years old) if necessary, on the condition that all pupils can be reached effectively.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Secondary Schools (generally for children ages 10 to 18)
institution_status: Secondary Schools allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Negative COVID-19 Test,Partial remote/distance learning  (e.g. Teachers with certain health conditions can tele-teach)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: For secondary education, pupils in the second and third grades will switch to a maximum of 50% contact education until 1 December. Before 1 December, we will evaluate whether up to 100% contact education will be possible again. For higher education, distance learning will be provided: For first-year students: until 1 December when they can follow contact education again. For older students, at least until the end of the calendar year. Teachers must have online meetings; the same applies for pedagogical study days. No physical team buildings are allowed. This is effective as of November 2, 2020.

description:
Belgium: The Consultative Committee is allowing classes to resume April 19th for nursery education, primary education, special needs secondary education, the first stage of secondary education, and the system of ‘learning and working’ in 100% full-time face-to-face education. However, 2nd and 3rd stage of secondary education is 50% face-to-face education. For higher education, only 1 day/week can be physically on campus. 
Exams can be taken in person. Indoor day trips will be permitted. Face masks for those in the fifth and sixth years of primary are still required. Interaction between classes is advised to be as limited as possible.
Depending on the covid situation at the time, 2nd and 3rd stage of secondary can more to 100% face-to-face education May 3rd.

description: In primary and nursery schools, a class (pupils and teachers) must go into quarantine as soon as 25% of the class or four pupils (instead of two) are infected. The quarantine period will also be shortened from seven days to only five days. Additionally, when a high-risk contact has taken place outside the classroom, and a child has to go into quarantine as a result, that child is allowed to leave quarantine to go to school. Partially vaccinated pupils or those who received their last dose more than five months ago must quarantine for seven days following a high-risk contact. However, they may leave quarantine after four days if they take a daily self-test with a negative result until day 7. A PCR test to end quarantine is no longer needed. For unvaccinated pupils, the rules remain the same: they will have to quarantine for ten days. However, they are allowed to leave quarantine after seven days if they take daily self-tests with a negative result until day 10 and strictly apply all preventive measures. The measures will take effect from 10 January and last until the carnival break (Monday 28 February to Sunday 6 March).
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
Belgian Vaccination Taskforce stated that people with reduced immunity will be invited for an extra COVID-19 vaccine dose from 13 September 2021. This additional dose will be considered as part of basic vaccination, not a booster.  
This third dose will now be offered to people over the age of 12 who are one of the following:
- Have a congenital immune disorder,
- Are on chronic dialysis,
- Have inflammatory diseases taking immunosuppressive drugs (e.g.
patients with Crohn’s disease, rheumatoid arthritis),
- Patients treated for cancer or who have received treatment for cancer
in the last three years,
- Patients who have undergone stem cell or organ transplants, including
before surgery,
- HIV-positive cases with a CD4 cell count of less than 200 per mm3 of
blood.

description:
On Saturday 27 November, the Ministers of Health in Belgium at the various levels of government agreed on the deployment of the booster dose of vaccine for the entire population.  For this booster dose, there is no priority group. The two criteria taken into account are the age of the person and the type and date of the vaccine already received.
In addition, the vaccines used in the booster dose are only the Moderna and Pfizer messenger RNA vaccines, regardless of which vaccine was given in the first dose.

description:
On 15th November 2021, The Belgian Federal Government accepts the ordinance for mandatory vaccination of healthcare workers from 1st April 2022. 
A transitional phase will apply between 1 January and 31 March, during which healthcare workers will have to prove that they have either been vaccinated against Covid-19 or have undergone a PCR test within 72 hours.
From 1 April when the full obligation comes into force for all healthcare staff, those who are not vaccinated will be dismissed.

description: The different Health ministers in Belgium on the 6th of July 2022 have decided that a new coronavirus booster campaign will kick off after the summer holidays. The campaign will focus on people above 50 years of age, care and health workers and vulnerable groups: they will be invited automatically to receive a booster jab. Others are encouraged to take a jab but will have to take the initiative themselves. The aim is to be ready for a (possible) new corona wave in autumn and/or winter.

description: Following the outbreak of COVID-19 and in order to guarantee safety and public health as well as to minimise the social-economic consequences as much as possible, the Flemish Parliament has taken several measures by issuing a decree on 20 March 2020. The Flemish Government effectively established the civil emergency on 20 March 2020, covering the period up to and including 17 July 2020.

description:
On March 26, 2020, the Belgian Parliament announces that it will adopt special legislation empowering the government to exercise limited emergency powers for three months from March 27, 2020 until June 27, 2020. The government gains the power to enact laws in the following policy categories, though the laws must be ratified by Parliament within a year after its adoption to remain valid.
- "combatting the spread of COVID19, including but not limited to maintaining public order and upholding public health;"
- "maintaining or increasing the necessary logistical and reception capacity, including but not limited to the security of supply;"
- "supporting (directly or indirectly) the financial and economic sectors, the (not for profit) sectors, individual enterprises and households in order to limit the impact of the pandemic;"
- "protecting the economical continuity, the financial stability, the free market and its consumers;"
- "modifying labour and social security law in order to protect workers' interests and the organisation of enterprises and government, in order to safeguard the economic interest of Belgium as well as the continuity of critical sectors."
- "reorganizing the judicial system."
- "EU measures concerning the COVID19 pandemic."
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Since Wednesday 18 March 2020 Belgium has banned non-essential travel abroad until the end of lockdown (5 April). Goods and services can still be transported across the border.

The Schengen external borders closure has been extended until May 15th, 2020. This prohibits entry into Belgium to most non-EEA travellers. description:

description:
15th of April, 2020: Belgium has banned non-essential travel abroad. Goods and services can still be transported across the border.

The following are considered essential movements:

professional journeys co-parenting schemes providing assistance to a vulnerable person living abroad attending a funeral within the family picking up someone in your family at an airport in one of our neighbouring countries taking care of your animals that are abroad

The following are considered non-essential movements:

tourism leisure shopping refuelling visiting an acquaintance visiting a family member abroad.

This policy is set to last until May 3rd, 2020. UPDATE: The original travel ban has been extended to May 3rd.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: Belgium: For areas designated as  Red Zones , arrivals are required to take a COVID-19 test on arrival and self-quarantine for seven days and take another test after five days. If the second test returns positive, the self-quarantine period is extended for a further seven days.

description: All passenger travel (by air, by rail and by sea) from the United Kingdom to Belgium is prohibited on Monday, December 21, 2020. This applies both to passengers with Belgium as their final destination as well as to passengers in transit through the country. This emergency measure came into effect at midnight for a period of 24 hours.  This is related to the announcement of the UK of an accelerated spreading of the coronavirus, due to a new variant of the COVID-19 virus.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Belgium: December 18th, 2020: Starting on the 25th of December, all non-residents coming from a red zone coming into Belgium must present a recent (within the last 48 hours) negative covid test.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
Belgium: January 23rd, 2021: The Consultative Committee has restricted recreational/tourist travel. All traveling to and from Belgium for recreational/tourist purposes are prohibited from January 27th to March 1st. The restrictions include air, sea, rail, and road travel. In order to travel in or out of Belgium, people need to have a solemn declaration form, Passenger Location Form, and all other necessary documents (employer testimony...). 
Only essential travel will be allowed. This includes compelling family reasons, humanitarian reasons (health or to assist the vulnerable), study reasons (exchange students, researchers with a host agreement), residents of border regions (they travel to Belgium as part of their daily lives), professional reasons, and miscellaneous (taking care of animals, urgent repairs, legal obligations...)
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On Oct. 11, 2021, Belgium is requiring that those who are immunized against the Coronavirus or who have recovered from the virus to have proof of documentation when returning to Belgium through the Passenger Locator Form (PLF). Proof of documentation must be certificate of vaccination or proof of recovery from Coronavirus. Travelers can add a screenshot or a pdf form of the QR code for proof of documention. They may also enter the code of the document themselves. Those without documentation are required to test for virus.

description:
Following the meeting of the Consultative Committee (held on the 11th February), it has been decided that the corona barometer will be changed to code orange. description:
"On Friday 4 March, the Consultative Committee met to take new measures following the positive evolution of the health situation in Belgium. Belgian residents if they do not hold one of the three COVID certificates (vaccination, test or recovery) and are coming from a country with an unfavourable situation, they have to be tested on the first day of their arrival (rapid antigen test or PCR test).

description:
May 4th: Belgium will introduce a new contact tracing strategy, from 11 May onward. The strategy looks as follows:

When a patient is tested, the doctor performing the test will ask the patient to record their contacts over the last few days.

From the middle of this week, patients infected with Covid-19 will be contacted by a call centre to ask who they have been in close contact with over the past few days. The form they filled out may be helpful during this call. People who have recently been in close contact with an infected person will also be called by the call centre. Their state of health will be assessed and, on that basis, they will be asked to take the necessary measures.

The infected patients’ general practitioner will already ask them whether they have been in close contact with certain people, such as people living in the same household. In this case, the general practitioner can issue a quarantine certificate for these people, even if the individuals concerned do not (yet) show symptoms and are fit for work. Individuals who have been issued with such a quarantine certificate must comply with the isolation measures. They can, however, work from home.

Under certain, strictly defined conditions this quarantine certificate may also be issued by the call centre under the responsibility of a hygiene inspector.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Belgium is reinforcing contact tracing in certain specific situations where the epidemiological risk is higher because of individuals being  active , i.e. mobile or exercising. Contact details are also requested at these locations, such as in wellness centres and at sports lessons. A full list of the locations concerned will be published in the Ministerial Order. They will be subject to the same obligations as the hospitality industry

description: In Belgium the self-isolation has been reduced from 14 days to seven. As of Wednesday, the number of days individuals displaying COVID-19 symptoms or people who have been in close proximity to someone who has tested positive for COVID-19 will be required to self-isolate for has been reduced from 14 days to seven. From October 1, face coverings will no longer be required in crowded outdoor public spaces unless specifically directed by local authorities.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Who a person has come into contact with over time
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
30 September: After having been rolled out to more than 10,000 users, the Coronalert application is now accessible to the entire Belgian population. This application is one of the tools used in the fight against Covid-19. The application works with green and red screens. A green screen means that the user is at low risk and that he/she had no high-risk contact. In case of a high-risk contact, the application will display a red screen. Two scenarios are possible. If you have symptoms of coronavirus, the application will advise you to contact your doctor. If you don’t have any symptoms, the application will suggest you to contact the contact centre which will provide more information about being tested.

Anyone who takes the test can receive the result via the app and automatically inform his/her high-risk contacts in case of a positive result
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type_sub_cat: Who a person has come into contact with over time
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: The operator or his delegate of the following establishments is obliged to register the contact data, which may be limited to a telephone number or an e-mail address, of the visitor or household participant, upon arrival: wellness centers; collective sports lessons; pools; casinos and automatic gambling rooms. description: Belgium: March 19th, 2020: Pharmaceutical companies and wholesale distributors must meet quotas in sales of paracetamol, a medication used to treat symptoms of Covid-19. description:
Belgium: The FAMHP has put in new measures to avoid medication shortages. Strategic stocks of hydroxychloroquine, Kaletra, and Rocuronium (curare) have been put in place in hospitals and Sufentanil
Atracurium besilate, and Rocuronium bromide will be distributed strategically to hospitals. 
There is also a distribution quota of some medicines like Esmeron, Nimbex, Morphine Sterop, Rapifen, Dipidolor Sufenta, Fentanyl and Hypnomidate to hospitals based on intensive care beds for Covid-19 patients. 
Derogation of the importation of foreign batches of clarithromycin, noradrenaline, sufentanil, alfentanil and hypnomidate has been granted. 
The FAMHP has asked hospitals to use medicines rationally and not stockpile them unnecessarily.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Belgium: In order to avoid stock shortages the FAMHP has declared a ban on the exportation of certain raw materials and medicines outside of the European Economic Area (EEA). All exports within EEA must be verified beforehand by FAMHP. 
A mandatory quota on wholesalers is limiting the sale quantities of the drugs and raw materials to the quantities corresponding to last year's sales for the same period with an increase of sales by a maximum of 50%. 
Hospitals, hospital pharmacies, and pharmacies must report excesses of 50% of stockpiles of drugs above one month's sales volume to the FAMHP in order for the agency to redistribute. 
There are 49 drugs involved in this ban, quota, and stockpile restriction as well as 53 raw materials.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From 19th of October, 2020 in Belgium non-medically trained individuals are allowed to act as nurses within hospitals, medical offices and other public health establishments.

description:
Belgium: The FAMHP has put in place a new version of the Alternative Test Protocol for surgical and comfort masks. Due to the shortage of masks and several masks not having the certificates, declarations, or test reports to demonstrate European or international requirements. This new test meets Bureau for Standardisation (NBN) directives for comfort masks. This test will make it that more masks meet standards and can be used legally.
The test states that when masks reach a Bacterial Filtration Efficiency of 70% they can be released as comfort masks. The tests are performed in authorised laboratories and results will be made public.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The Belgian government announced it will be providing one billion euros to general hospitals to pay for expenses linked to the COVID-19 crisis on Jun. 7 2020. The stimulus is to be provided in two batches of 500 million euros. The first will be provided immediately and the second in October 2020.

description:
On 30 March Belgium is aiming to significantly boost its capacity to test patients for the new coronavirus (Covid-19) to 10,000 per day, up from the current 2,000.
An initiative to increase the number of daily coronavirus tests was launched last week by Digital Minister Philippe de Backer and Health Minister Maggie De Block.
“We follow a strategy to progressively increase the number of tests from 2,000 to 10,000 per day,” De Backer wrote in an online statement.
Currently, the official guidelines on testing dictate that only medical staff and hospitalised patients with apparent symptoms should be tested.

 UPDATE: The conditions and place of testing changed. End of policy.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
May 4th: Belgium changes its testing strategy. Testing will (again) be scaled up from 11 May onward. The strategy looks as follows:

"The test criteria have been expanded to test all symptomatic patients. People who have been in contact with infected patients can also be tested according to established guidelines. 

Any individual doctor may carry out the tests on his patients, provided he has the sampling equipment required as well as the necessary protective equipment. He will then work in close collaboration with the laboratory which usually processes his analysis requests and will obtain his supplies from this same laboratory. Alternatively, he can also refer his patients to a triage centre set up by a circle of general practitioners, which will have testing facilities in place and organised itself for this purpose. 

Triage centres that have the analyses carried out by the federal testing platform will be supplied with protective equipment and sampling devices by the federal platform. This platform will also ensure the samples are collected and dispatched to analysis laboratories." UPDATE: May 4th: Belgium changes its testing strategy. It now looks as follows:

"The test criteria have been expanded to test all symptomatic patients. People who have been in contact with infected patients can also be tested according to established guidelines.

Any individual doctor may carry out the tests on his patients, provided he has the sampling equipment required as well as the necessary protective equipment. He will then work in close collaboration with the laboratory which usually processes his analysis requests and will obtain his supplies from this same laboratory. Alternatively, he can also refer his patients to a triage centre set up by a circle of general practitioners, which will have testing facilities in place and organised itself for this purpose.

Triage centres that have the analyses carried out by the federal testing platform will be supplied with protective equipment and sampling devices by the federal platform. This platform will also ensure the samples are collected and dispatched to analysis laboratories."
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Belgium: For those travelling within or out of the country will receive a text message through contact tracing with an activation code to be tested. Testing will occur on the 7th day of quarantine, however. If the test is late, a person must continue to be in quarantine until they receive their results. If it returns positive, then the person must quarantine for an additional 7 days and take the test again on the last day. 
People who suspect high-risk contact, but have not received a text, cannot be tested. 
Results will be uploaded to the covid-test portal or the coronalert application. Doctors are no longer necessary as go-betweens.

For people with symptoms rapid antigen tests must be performed within the first 5 days after the onset of symptoms, otherwise their sensitivity decreases significantly (risk of false negatives).If COVID-19 is strongly suspected and a rapid test was negative, or in the case of vulnerable persons experiencing symptoms of COVID-19, a PCR test must be requested.

description:
The free PCR tests prior to travel are intended for people in Belgium from 26 June 2021 who have not yet had the opportunity to be (fully) vaccinated.
Specifically, you must meet the following conditions:
You are 6 years of age or older
You have your main residence in Belgium
You have not yet received an invitation for vaccination
OR you were invited for vaccination once, less than 35 days ago, and have not yet received your second invitation
OR you got your first dose less than 35 days after receiving the first invitation, but you have not yet been fully vaccinated.

description:
Belgium: Testing and quarantine rules
The Consultative Committee has taken note of the decision of the Health Ministers who, on the basis of the latest scientific information on the Omicron variant, have changed the testing and quarantine policy with effect from 10 January.

In this new testing and quarantine policy, self-testing has become increasingly important. Self-tests are available in supermarkets and pharmacies. For people who benefit from an increased allowance, self-tests are available in pharmacies for €1 per test (a maximum of 4 self-tests per person every 14 days).

description:
April 15th: Previously, no visitors were in allowed in Belgian nursing homes. From April 21st onward, however, residents of residential facilities – i.e. rest and care homes or centres for people with disabilities – will be allowed to be visited by a pre-designated person. 
The condition is that the person in question has not shown any symptoms of the disease in the past two weeks. It must always be the same person. The residential facilities will be able to organise these visits themselves. These rules will also apply to people who live in isolation and are unable to move around.

It is unclear when this policy is slated to end.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: In Belgium: all individuals are mandated to stay home except for the following: to attend the activities and establishments now open, to access ATMs and postal services, access medical services, attend to personal matters, participate in assistance to older individuals, minors or persons with disabilities, take care of animals, go to work, participate in a volunteering program, go for a short exercise activity.

description: In Belgium, all individuals are still mandated to stay at home, or in a secondary residence of which they have been owners for at least one year. Belgium, 12 March: Given the major impact of this pandemic on the entire socio-economic fabric, various crisis units have been put together to operationalise the crisis management:
The Socio-economic Unit is chaired by the FPS Economy and is made up of representatives of the Ministers for the Economy, Employment and Public Health and for SMEs, as well as from the FPS Economy, Employment, and Labour, Mobility, Social Security and from the Government Department (POD) Social Integration. description:
Since Thursday 12 March 2020, Belgium has been in the “federal phase of crisis management”.

The government is assisted by experts in various fields. These experts advise the government on the measures to be taken. These experts sit together in an evaluation cell (CELEVAL).
Celeval is chaired by the FPS Public Health and consists of:

Health experts
Virologists
Economists
Psychologists
Behavioural experts
Communication experts

description:
On 19 March 2020, a social emergency task force was set up in the Walloon Region. In context of the coronavirus epidemic, the task force aims to respond to issues that impact vulnerable groups.  It is 
coordinated by the cabinet of the Minister-President and consists of representatives of all Walloon  Ministers, as well as representatives of the RWLP, the Federation of Public Social Welfare Centres  (CPAS), the Federation of Social Services (FDSS), the Walloon Public Service and the Walloon Agency for Quality of Life (AViQ). Depending on the topics, other stakeholders will also be consulted. This task force was set up in collaboration with the Walloon Network against Poverty (RWLP).

description: Along with other goals for vaccination, the Intraminsterial Conference on Public Health announces the creation of a taskforce to help with the vaccination programme. The taskforce is called "Operationalising covid-19 vaccination strategy" and will decide necessary actions and assist with realising the strategy by coordination. It will consist of scientists, representatives from federal and provincial authorities, crisis managers and representatives from companies and technical working groups. It will be led by Dirk Ramaekers. Within the taskforce, there will be a part dedicated to societal debate and communication, led by Yvon Englert.

description:
Belgium: At the request of the minister of public health, Frank Vandenbroucke, the national government has started the project Community Health Workers that seeks to promote the available health care in relation to Covid-19. 
50 health care workers, mostly social workers, will be deployed to be the link between vulnerable groups and the health care system. Their role will be to better the access to the health care system, help vulnerable groups understand and use the health care system, and point out the inequalities and structural issues within the health care system, especially in relation to issues pertaining to Covid-19. 
The project is funded with a 2. 975.000 euros grant. The project is set to end at the end of December 2021.

description: April 7th: Belgium installs so-called "Gemeentelijke Administratieve Sancties" i.e. fines gives by cities or municipalities and not by the police. The fines will be given to citizens violating anti-corona measures and they will amount to 250 euros.

description:
15th of April: Belgium installs so-called “Gemeentelijke Administratieve Sancties” i.e. fines gives by cities or municipalities and not by the police. The fines will be given to citizens violating anti-corona measures and they will amount to 250 euros.
Policy is set to last until May 3rd. UPDATE: The "gemeentelijke administratieve sancties" (fines given by cities/municipalities instead of the police) have been extended to May 3rd.

description: As of 11 May 2020 contact tracing is fully operational in Flanders:  "After a start-up phase, contact investigations in Flanders are ready to call people across Flanders on an unprecedented scale, to question contacts and to provide advice on how to prevent contamination. Today, about 735 employees started to conduct telephone contact inquiries. In addition, employees of various health insurance funds are ready to strengthen the call centres with advice and to start home visits in the coming days when telephone contact investigations fail."  (    Kept on 1 as the other main region (Wallonia) will follow on 18 May 2020.

description:
The Belgian authorities have continued the information campaigns since the start of the pandemic and kept communicating about the measures needed to stop the spread of the virus. The campaign, which the FPS Chancellery of the Prime Minister was coordinating at a federal level, has come about in collaboration with the FPS Public Health and the National Crisis Centre, in consultation with the communities and regions and with their full cooperation.

The priority was to remind the population at large of the most critical messages. A particular website has been set up to publish the epidemic report every day. Details of the data have been available to the public since 15 March. Other public health messages, such as respecting hygiene measures, respecting social distancing, respecting safety measures, and persevering and staying calm, was disseminated via radio and TV slots, social media, Internet banners, posters or screens in public places, in bus shelters, supermarkets, pharmacies, and on cash machines. All of these messages were in the three national languages of French, Dutch, German, and another thirty languages [38]. Moreover, the messages via radio, print, Internet, or social media adopt the style, colors, and tone of the messaging from the Crisis Centre and the FPS Public Health in order to maintain a coherent and effective approach to all the government’s communication efforts
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)

description:
Belgium: November 27th, 2020: 
Belgium's federal government launched a new campaign, "1 Team of 11 Million Players", which plays on the country's love for soccer/football, to help people persevere through the Covid-19 second wave. The campaign urges people to continue to follow and keep track of the strict covid guidelines in order to minimise the spread of covid. The campaign's message is that only together will Belgium defeat Covid-19. The campaign will be spread through social media, all major TV channels, and national newspapers. The campaign will also put up a tifo (tribune clothe, often used in soccer/football to support teams) in Antwerp and Brussels. The campaign will run until the end of January.

description:
Belgium: Since the beginning of May, all people with symptoms and close contacts of COVID-positive people are tested. The following isolation and quarantine rules apply:
• For symptomatic people: If results are positive, people have to isolate at home for at least 7 additional days after receiving their test results. If they have no symptoms at day 7, isolation can be stopped.
• For asymptomatic close contacts: Up to October 1st, if the test result was negative, close contacts must remain in quarantine for 14 days after the last risk contact.

But even those who take a negative test still have to stay at home: up to fourteen days since the last high-risk contact with the patient.

description:

 UPDATE: The original duration of quarantine was 14 days. It has been shortened to 7 days.

description:
Belgium: December 30th, 2020: The federal government has enforced new quarantine rules. Residents and non-residents, coming from a stay of longer than 48 hours in a red zone must quarantine. The quarantine can only be ended after receiving a negative PCR test, 7 days after they started their quarantine. They must never the less be tested on the first and seventh day of quarantine. Starting on the 2nd of January, travellers will receive a text telling them when to present themselves to a testing centre. 
However, there are three exceptions. First, students can interrupt their quarantine in order to take an exam. Second, critical essential workers can go back to work with a testimonial from their employer. Third, people who travelled due to work can interrupt their quarantine if they have a testimonial from their employer on the reason for travel, this third exception only applies until the 4th of January 2021. 
This policy will be in place until January 15th, 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries

description: People who test positive for Covid-19 from 27 January 2021must  isolate themselves for 10 days. After a high-risk contact or travel to Belgium, the quarantine period also remains ten days. This period may be reduced to a minimum of seven days, provided that a negative test has been performed no earlier than seven days after exposure.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Belgium is dropping the requirement for fully vaccinated people to self-isolate if they come into close contact with someone infected with COVID-19. The rule applies to anyone who received their second vaccine dose or booster in the last five months but does not apply to unvaccinated people, who must still isolate for 10 days. This period can be cut to seven days however, with a daily negative antigen test through day 10, broadcaster VRT reported. For vaccinated people who fall outside of the five-month gap, they must also isolate for 10 days, but can be released on day four with a daily negative antigen test through day 10. The new rules, backed by federal and regional health ministers on Tuesday, will come into effect on January 10.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From 10 January, people who have either already received a booster dose or those who received their last shot of the “basic vaccination” up to five months ago will no longer have to quarantine following a high-risk contact. Meanwhile, for people who have not yet received the booster vaccination or who received their last dose more than five months ago, the quarantine period will be shortened following a high-risk contact: they may leave after four days following a high-risk contact provided that a daily self-test is taken until day seven. These people will also no longer need a PCR test to end quarantine.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: People who test positive for Covid-19 from 27 January 2021must  isolate themselves for 10 days. After a high-risk contact or travel to Belgium, the quarantine period also remains ten days. This period may be reduced to a minimum of seven days, provided that a negative test has been performed no earlier than seven days after exposure. UPDATE: A person who tests positive will have to isolate themselves for 7 days (not 10 days) and 3 additional days of vigilance if they do not develop symptoms or have mild complaints.

description:
On Tuesday 17 March, the National Security Council, which has been expanded to include the Ministers-President, decided to take additional measures. On the one hand, these measures are based on the evolution of the spread of Covid-19 in Belgium.
Companies - regardless of size - are obliged to organize teleworking for every function where this is possible, without exception.
For those for whom this organization is not possible, social distancing will be strictly respected. This rule applies to both the performance of the work and the transport organized by the employer. If it is impossible for companies to meet these obligations, they must close their doors.
If the authorities establish that the social distancing measures are not being complied with, the company will in the first instance be fined a heavy one; in case of non-compliance after the sanction, the company will have to close.

The measures set out below will enter into force at noon on Wednesday 18 March and shall be maintained until 5 April. The situation will continue to be assessed on a daily basis and further changes may be made as the situation evolves.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
17th of March, National Security Council including Prime Ministers decided to take additional measures in Belgium:
Access to supermarkets will be regulated, with a limitation to a specific number of customers (1 person per 10m² and a maximum presence of 30 minutes).
Cafés are obliged to put their patio furniture inside.
Night shops may remain open until 10 p.m., subject to social distancing instructions .

description:
May 6th: Previously, all non-essential businesses in Belgium had to close their doors. Since May 11th, all regular stores can open again (at earlier stages, fabric stores, garden centres and DIY stores were allowed to open already).

Yet, many non-essential businesses must remain closed still. These include:
- Markets (only individual market stalls (food and non-food) will be allowed by the local authorities and at the usual locations)
- Cafes, bars, restaurants and festivity halls
- Recreational, cultural and tourist sites 
- Hairdressers, beautycians and other businesses that require physical contact
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
institution_status: This type of business  ("Restaurants") is closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
May 6th: Previously, all non-essential businesses in Belgium had to close their doors. Since May 11th, all regular stores can open again (at earlier stages, fabric stores, garden centres and DIY stores were allowed to open already).

On May 13th Belgium announces that certain non-essential businesses to open their door again. These are "professions requiring close contact with customers" (e.g. beautycians) as well as markets and nature attractions like zoos.
These policy relaxations are part of Belgium's exit strategy, phase 2 and will take effect on May 18th.

The non-essential businesses must remain closed include:
- Cafes, bars, restaurants and festivity halls UPDATE: adding end date specs

description:
From 8 June, 2020 in Belgium non-contact sports activities can be resumed, both indoor and outdoor, amateur or professional, league and training. Gyms and fitness rooms may also be reopened, subject to protocol.

However:

Contact sports (e.g. judo, boxing, football, etc.) should always be limited to "contactless" training.
As far as sports facilities are concerned, the protocols will also have to be followed. Changing rooms and showers will still not be accessible.
Swimming pools, saunas and wellness centres have to remain closed at this stage.

description:
Belgium will go ahead with the next phase of its exit plan out of the lockdown from 1 July, announced Prime Minister Sophie Wilmès during a press conference on Wednesday. Phase 4: 1 July

The 6 golden rules will continue to apply. Here’s a refresher on what they are.

You can have closer contact with 15 people, instead of the previous 10. This can be 15 different people every week.

Swimming pools, wellness centres, amusement parks, casinos and gaming halls can reopen. Reception halls can also reopen, but for a maximum of 50 people, if they apply the protocols.

description: The National Security Council, expanded with the prime ministers, met on 23 July to take stock of the health situation in our country and to take the necessary measures. The National Security Council has adopted a series of measures that will apply across the country from Saturday, July 25. The customers of the catering industry will be asked to leave an email address or a telephone number , so that they can be notified in time in the event of an infection. This information will be destroyed after 14 days and cannot be used for any other purpose than the fight against the Coronavirus.

description:
Belgium: October 16th, 2020: The Consultative Committee has decided to move the entire country into alert level 4 from October 19th, 2020 until November 19th, 2020 (one month). Restrictions for businesses include: 

- Markets and fairs will remain open, but no selling of food and drink and flea markets, bric-a-brac markets and small Christmas markets are forbidden. 
- Teleworking will be mandatory wherever possible. 
- Cafes and restaurants will be closed, picking-up limited to before 10 pm with a ban on selling alcohol past 8 pm.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential

description:
The Expat Welcome Desk informs expats in Brussels about the latest measures taken in Belgium to limit the spread of Covid-19. In Brussels Region: closure of cultural venues (museums, exhibitions halls, etc.) and closure of recreational facilities including amusement parks, cinemas, betting agencies, casinos, etc.
Night clubs are closed, same as coffee shops, cafeterias, bars. Shops are allowed to open only one person to do the shopping (+1 minor). Only disabled people are allowed to be accompanied by an adult. All shops close at 8 pm.  Restaurants are also closed but take-away meals authorised until 10 pm.

description:
Belgium: October 30th, 2020: As of November 2nd, the Consultative Committee put in place new business restrictions:

- All non-essential stores must close. Pick-up and deliveries are allowed, but when picking up goods, no access to the store is permitted.
-All non-medical contact professions must stop operating, including hairdressers, make-up artists, wellness centers, massage parlours, and beauty salons.

These will be in place until December 13th, 2020 when the Consultative Committee will reassess.

UPDATE: All non-essential stores can open on December 1st, 2020 with restrictions, including the mandatory washing of hands, mask-wearing, and social distancing, visible prevention measure guidelines, and hand sanitiser must be used before entering stores. Furthermore, shoppers must shop individually and there is a maximum shopping time of 30 minutes per individual. Non-medical contact businesses must remain closed until the 13th of December, 2020. UPDATE: The original policy closed all non-essential businesses and non-medical contact businesses, but in the change of the policy, non-essential businesses are allowed to open while non-medical contact businesses must remain closed. Furthermore, the original restrictions for both were to last until December 13th, non-essential businesses can open on the 1st of December, while non-medical contact businesses must remain closed until the 13th of December 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_status: This type of business  ("Personal Grooming Businesses") is closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Belgium: As per the summer four-step plan, in the first step to be in place on June 9th, catering and parties and major events can restart. 
The catering industry will reopen indoors between 8am and 10pm. The maximum number of people per table is 4 or one household per table. A distance of least 1.5 meters must be maintained between tables. 
Outdoor catering establishments will be able to remain open until 11.30pm instead of 10pm. The table rules will remain the same: 4 people or one household per table and a distance of 1.5 meters between tables. Parties and receptions: up to 50 people indoors. For the remainder, they must follow the rules for the catering industry.

description:
Belgium: The Consultative Committee has released a four-step summer plan that begins on June 9th and is to go until the 1st of September, 2021. The plan is contingent on beds in intensive care filled by covid-19 patients remain below 500 and vaccinations continue as planned. 

The first step is to begin on the 9th of June, 2021. For businesses, the plan mandates that teleworking remain mandatory, with 1 day in the office per week. There are to never be more than 20% of the employees present at the same time. Testing is highly recommended. 
Cinemas, bowling alleys, casinos, fruit machine halls and bookmakers may reopen with ventilation protocols. This is also the case for indoor areas of nature parks, zoos and amusement parks as well as indoor playgrounds, indoor recreation, tropical swimming pools and unmanned tanning beds. 
Fairs and non-professional bric-a-brac and flea markets will also be able to take place again. They must be organised according to the same rules as for markets. 
Fitness centres can reopen with ventilation protocols and the mandatory use of a visible air quality meter. 
Door-to-door sales is permitted again, as are the activities of sex workers.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Commercial Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Hygiene and sanitation measures required,Other condition not specified above (please provide detail in the text entry)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Belgium: The Consultative Committee has released a four-step summer plan that begins on June 9th and is to go until the 1st of September, 2021. The plan is contingent on beds in intensive care filled by covid-19 patients remain below 500 and vaccinations continue as planned. 

The first step is to begin on the 9th of June, 2021. For businesses, the plan mandates that teleworking remain mandatory, with 1 day in the office per week. There are to never be more than 20% of the employees present at the same time. Testing is highly recommended. 
Cinemas, bowling alleys, casinos, fruit machine halls and bookmakers may reopen with ventilation protocols. This is also the case for indoor areas of nature parks, zoos and amusement parks as well as indoor playgrounds, indoor recreation, tropical swimming pools and unmanned tanning beds. 
Fairs and non-professional bric-a-brac and flea markets will also be able to take place again. They must be organised according to the same rules as for markets. 
Fitness centres can reopen with ventilation protocols and the mandatory use of a visible air quality meter. 
Door-to-door sales is permitted again, as are the activities of sex workers.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential

description: Belgium: As of the 26th of April, restaurants are allowed to reopen and gatherings of 10 people are permitted. However, conditions for terraces have been put in place by the Consultative Committee. A maximum of 4 people, or one household, are allowed at one table. There must be at least 1.5 meters between tables. Face masks are mandatory for staff and any non-seated customers. You can not order directly from the bar, there is only table seating. Customers can only go inside briefly to use the washroom, pay, or reach the terrace. Opening hours are limited to 8am till 10pm.

description: As of Feb 15, 2022, Belgian employees will be able to work a four-day week after the government on Tuesday agreed a new labour accord aimed at bringing flexibility to an otherwise rigid labour market. Employees who request it will be able to work up to 10 hours per day if trade unions agree, instead of the maximum 8 now, in order to work one day less per week for the same pay. Belgians will also be able to choose to work more during one week and less the following one, allowing people to better manage their work-private life, in case of co-parenting for example.

description:
As announced on March 10, the evolution of the spread of the coronavirus is assessed every day, as the situation is constantly changing. In light of the most recent developments, the National Security Council met on Thursday 12 March in the presence of and in consultation with the Ministers-President. 
These measures are in effect from Friday midnight until 3 April. As before, the ongoing situation will be assessed on a daily basis.

Public transport will continue to function normally, but trips should be limited to only those that are necessary. Flexible working times should prevent overloading public transport.

description:
The National Security Council (NSC), extended with the ministers-president had a meeting today, Wednesday 13 May. On the basis of the GEES experts' report, the NSC decided to start phase 2 of the phase-out plan as from 18 May. A second aspect in this phase is culture. The NSC has decided that museums and cultural sights - historic buildings and monuments, castles, citadels - can be reopened as from 18 May, provided they set up an online or telephone ticketing system and take the necessary measures to avoid drawing crowds. Libraries can remain open, under the same conditions as now.
Natural tourist sites, such as zoos, will also be allowed to reopen, provided that they introduce an online or telephone ticketing system to restrict public access, draw up a circulation plan and that cafeterias and restaurants remain closed, as well as any rides and playgrounds.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)

description:
The National Security Council (NSC), extended with the ministers-president had a meeting today, Wednesday 13 May. On the basis of the GEES experts' report, the NSC decided to start phase 2 of the phase-out plan as from 18 May. A second aspect in this phase is culture. The NSC has decided that museums and cultural sights - historic buildings and monuments, castles, citadels - can be reopened as from 18 May, provided they set up an online or telephone ticketing system and take the necessary measures to avoid drawing crowds. Libraries can remain open, under the same conditions as now.
Natural tourist sites, such as zoos, will also be allowed to reopen, provided that they introduce an online or telephone ticketing system to restrict public access, draw up a circulation plan and that cafeterias and restaurants remain closed, as well as any rides and playgrounds.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
institution_status: This service provided by the government is provided with conditions attached
institution_conditions: Hygiene and sanitation measures required,Restriction  of number of people allowed to access this service
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
The Expat Welcome Desk informs expats in Brussels about the latest measures taken in Belgium to limit the spread of Covid-19. In Brussels Region: closure of cultural venues (museums, exhibitions halls, etc.) and closure of recreational facilities including amusement parks, cinemas, betting agencies, casinos, etc.
Night clubs are closed, same as coffee shops, cafeterias, bars. Shops are allowed to open only one person to do the shopping (+1 minor). Only disabled people are allowed to be accompanied by an adult. All shops close at 8 pm.  Restaurants are also closed but take-away meals authorised until 10 pm.

description:
Belgium: February 12th, 2021: On the proposition by deputy minister Petra De Sutter, the federal government is providing measures in order to better support federal government workers working from home. 
Measures in six areas will be implemented. The measures are to be put in place to help with burn-out, reinforcing communication within the federal administrations, better image strategy for workers linked to working with the covid-19 pandemic, a new process deciding who works from home, training for administration leaders as well as for collaborators, and the buying of new materials and technology to help handicapped federal workers working from home.

description: Children under 13 will be allowed to play in public playgrounds again from May 27, 2021, after Belgium authorities were given the green light to reopen them. Only children under the age of 12 will be allowed into the public areas and accompanying adults must keep the mandatory 1.5 metres of social distance between each other. Indoor playgrounds will not be allowed to reopen and outdoor playgrounds or play areas in natural parks or in places like museums or zoos can reopen but a staff member must be present to enforce the rules.

description:
From 8 June, 2020 in Belgium cultural activities may resume without an audience present. Performances with an audience - including cinemas - can be resumed from 1 July, but only subject to specific rules regarding crowd management, such as respecting the safety distance in the audience and a maximum of 200 attendees.

Activities should be organised in such a way as to avoid gatherings of too many people, e.g. outside the venue.

When people take part in cultural and leisure activities, wearing a mask is recommended at all times.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: All Recreational or commercial events allowed to occur with conditions

description:
Belgium: October 16th, 2020: The Consultative Committee has decided to move the entire country into alert level 4 on October 19th, 2020 until November 19th, 2020 (one month). Restrictions include: 

-Cuddle contacts (close contacts) limited to one person. 
- Private gatherings limited to the same 4 people every two-week window. - Outdoor gatherings limited to 4 people. 
- Receptions and banquets catered for by a professional caterer/catering company are forbidden.
- Professional sports competitions attendance will be halved from 400 to 200 spectators, canteens and drinking establishments must be closed.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Belgium: October 30th, 2020: As of November 2nd, 2020, the Consultative Committee put in place new mass gathering restrictions:

-Marriages can only take place with the spouses, witnesses, and civil registrars
-Funerals are limited to 15 attendees. No meal or reception afterwards is allowed
-Prayer houses can remain open, but gatherings are limited to 4 people with masks and social distancing. No services to be held.
-Outdoor mass gatherings limited to 4 people with masks and social distancing rules (1.5-meter distancing)

This policy will be in place until the 13th of December when the Consultative Committee will reassess.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Attendance at religious services restricted (e.g. mosque/church closings)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Belgium: The Consultative Committee has published a new outdoor gathering plan. As of March 8th, 2021, 10 people can meet outside together, but a distance of 1.5 meters must still be kept. 
A priority is being given to children and young people. Organised outdoor gatherings (including sports) for children 13 and under is limited to 10 people outside and 25 inside. For young people, aged 19 and younger, a limit of 10 people is in place for organised outdoor gatherings. Audiences for organised outdoor gatherings of children and youth is limited to 1 per participant.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

UPDATE: Due to the rise in covid cases among all age groups, the plan has been put on hold, except for outdoor gatherings of youth which will remain limited to 10 people. This takes effect on March 19th, 2021.

description:
Belgium: As per the summer four-step plan, in the first step to be in place on June 9th, events (cultural, sports, shows…) can start up again. 
Indoors: up to 200 people or 75% of the room capacity, seated, with face masks, and at a safe distance from each other. 
Outdoors: up to 400 people, with face masks and at a safe distance from each other. Non-professional sports: up to 50 people indoors and 100 people outdoors (except for contact sports).
Ceremonies, weddings, and funerals: up to 100 people indoors and 200 people outdoors allowed.

description:
Belgium: In step 2 of the four-step plan starting the 1st of July, events like cultural performances, shows and sports competitions can take place indoors with up to 2000 people or 80% of the room capacity present. They must be seated, with face masks and at a safe distance from each other. Outdoors up to 2500 people are allowed. Face masks and at a safe distance from each other are required. However, non-professional sports can occur without restrictions. 
Youth activities, camps, and social activities can have up to 100 people, with an overnight stay permitted. Pre-testing is highly recommended.

description: On September 1, certain restrictions were relaxed in Belgium, with the exception of Brussels. Wearing a mask will no longer be compulsory at indoor events gathering up to 200 people, unless local authorities decide to maintain rules to the contrary. Larger events can still be organized, however, these requires the Covid Safe Ticket, which indicates proof of full vaccination, a recent negative test result or the presence of antibodies following a recent coronavirus infection.

description:
Belgium: [December 3, 2021] Today, the Consultative Committee has discussed the epidemiological situation in our country. To reduce the pressure on our health system, it has been decided to limit indoor activities, to bring forward the Christmas holidays for pre-school and primary school education to 20 December and to switch to hybrid education in secondary schools. People are also urged to limit social contacts indoors as much as possible.
All indoor activities and gatherings are prohibited for the time being, including organised activities, but with the exception of: sports,
private gatherings organised at home or in a small tourist accommodation,
weddings and funerals.
Indoor sports competitions must be organised without an audience. Minor participants may be accompanied by two adults.
These measures will take effect on Saturday 4 December 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
Belgium On 8th of March 2022. 
Events
Indoors - Practically no measures. No use of a Covid Safe Ticket (CST). Only use of CO2 meter is mandatory.
Outdoors - Practically no measures. For closed tents or covered terraces, the indoor air standards apply.
Hospitality industry: Bars, restaurants
Indoors - Virtually no measures: no closing time, no CST, no facemasks (including for staff in the hospitality sector). Use of CO2 meter obligatory.
Outdoors - Also, virtually no measures. For closed tents or covered terraces, the indoor air standards apply.
Leisure
Indoors - Practically no measures apply. Extra attention should be paid to good ventilation.
Outdoors - No measures apply.

description:
On Tuesday 17 March, the National Security Council, which has been expanded to include the Ministers-President, decided to take additional measures. On the one hand, these measures are based on the evolution of the spread of Covid-19 in Belgium.
Companies - regardless of size - are obliged to organize teleworking for every function where this is possible, without exception.
For those for whom this organization is not possible, social distancing will be strictly respected. This rule applies to both the performance of the work and the transport organized by the employer. If it is impossible for companies to meet these obligations, they must close their doors.
If the authorities establish that the social distancing measures are not being complied with, the company will in the first instance be fined a heavy one; in case of non-compliance after the sanction, the company will have to close.

The measures set out below will enter into force at noon on Wednesday 18 March and shall be maintained until 5 April. The situation will continue to be assessed on a daily basis and further changes may be made as the situation evolves.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at All or unspecified businesses
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On the basis of recommendations from the Group of Experts in charge of the Exit Strategy (GEES), the National Security Council met today, Friday 24 April, in the Egmont Palace to determine the exit strategy from the corona crisis. Covering the mouth and nose is important when scaling down the measures. This can be done using a so-called comfort mask or an alternative means of protection such as a scarf or a bandana. This is:

recommended in public places
mandatory on public transport for users aged 12 years and over. This measure will enter into force on 4 May. A mask alone does not provide adequate protection, it should be considered within the wider use of mouth masks, hygiene measures and physical distance.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside Unspecified outdoor spaces
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied),Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: From May 11th, driving instructors are allowed to resume teaching, and from May 18th, all tests, practical and theoretical, in the AM, A, C, and D categories will be possible again. From May 25th, practical tests for the B, BE, and G categories will be permitted again. However, certain measures will become mandatory such as wearing a face mask in the car during lessons or the practical exams. Centers will also disinfect the car each time. People who are feeling ill are recommended to make another appointment.

description:
The National Security Council (NSC), extended with the ministers-president had a meeting today, Wednesday 13 May. On the basis of the GEES experts' report, the NSC decided to start phase 2 of the phase-out plan as from 18 May. A second aspect in this phase is culture. The NSC has decided that museums and cultural sights - historic buildings and monuments, castles, citadels - can be reopened as from 18 May, provided they set up an online or telephone ticketing system and take the necessary measures to avoid drawing crowds. Libraries can remain open, under the same conditions as now.
Natural tourist sites, such as zoos, will also be allowed to reopen, provided that they introduce an online or telephone ticketing system to restrict public access, draw up a circulation plan and that cafeterias and restaurants remain closed, as well as any rides and playgrounds.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Tourist Sites
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Starting from the 18th of May, 2020 in Belgium in beauty institutes, non-medical pedicure institutes, manicure salons, hairdressing salons, barbers and tattoo and piercing studios, the following modalities apply to clients' reception: customers can only come in by appointment in the strictly necessary duration of the service, waiting rooms and toilets can not be used for customers, workstations must be separated by a distance of at least 1.5 meters; and it is forbidden to offer food or drinks. Any person from the age of 12 is held to cover his mouth and nose by means of a mask or any other alternative in fabric.

description:
In Belgium performances with an audience - including cinemas - can be resumed from 1 July, but only subject to specific rules regarding crowd management, such as respecting the safety distance in the audience and a maximum of 200 attendees.
Activities should be organised in such a way as to avoid gatherings of too many people, e.g. outside the venue.  When people take part in cultural and leisure activities, wearing a mask is recommended at all times.

description: Starting from the 8th of June, 2020 In Belgium the safety distance remains valid, except for people within the same family, for children under the age of 12 with each other and for people with closer contact, i.e. the expanded bubble. ( Because of the option for each family to define an "expanded bubble" (10 people that can change weekly), H6=2G is kept as masks must be worn in specific public spaces (e.g. public transportation) but not in all public places with people present.

description:
From 8th of June, 2020 in Belgium the rules regarding safety distance continue to apply, except for people within the same family, for children under the age of 12 and for people with whom there is closer contact, i.e. the extended bubble. Those who cannot respect the safety distance have to wear a mouth mask.
It is possible to have closer contact with 10 different people every week, in addition to the family members (= extended personal bubble). This is an individual right. These 10 people can change from one week to the next.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: Starting from the 29th of July, 2020 In Belgium contacts outside every household will be limited to the same five people over the next four weeks, as the so-called “social bubble” now applies to a house and its occupants and not to individuals. description: Belgium, 23 September: As far as wearing the mouth mask is concerned, this remains mandatory when the safety distance cannot be guaranteed. However, as it is useless to make it mandatory anywhere, anytime, wearing a face mask will no longer be mandatory outdoors from October 1, except in high-traffic areas where the safety distance cannot be respected (determined by the local authorities) and in specific covered areas. Places, such as on public transport, in shops or cinemas and regardless of the number of people (for a complete list, consult the ministerial order).

description: Flemish-speaking: Safety measures have been tightened in all Flemish-speaking schools. Face masks are made compulsory for pupils older than 12 in the schoolyard unless they can keep a distance. Secondary schools can provide distance learning for second and third grades (students from 14 to 18 years old) if necessary, on the condition that all pupils can be reached effectively. In universities, 20 percent of students will be allowed to attend on-site, while the rest must follow classes remotely. Half of first-year students can attend on-site. However, almost all higher education institutions have switched to digital classes, even though they are not obliged to do so by the Flemish government. French-speaking: Classes in secondary schools will be done virtually from October 28 on; no pupils will be allowed on site. All university courses are now virtual, including for first-year students. There will no longer be any on-site presence until November 19. In Flanders, safety measures have been tightened; secondary schools can provide distance learning for second and third grades (students from 14 to 18 years old) if necessary, on the condition that all pupils can be reached effectively.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside Secondary Schools (generally for children ages 10 to 18)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
Belgium: The Consultative Committee is allowing classes to resume April 19th for nursery education, primary education, special needs secondary education, the first stage of secondary education, and the system of ‘learning and working’ in 100% full-time face-to-face education. However, 2nd and 3rd stage of secondary education is 50% face-to-face education. For higher education, only 1 day/week can be physically on campus. 
Exams can be taken in person. Indoor day trips will be permitted. Face masks for those in the fifth and sixth years of primary are still required. Interaction between classes is advised to be as limited as possible.
Depending on the covid situation at the time, 2nd and 3rd stage of secondary can more to 100% face-to-face education May 3rd.

Belgium: The Consultative Committee is allowing classes to resume April 19th for nursery education, primary education, special needs secondary education, the first stage of secondary education, and the system of ‘learning and working’ in 100% full-time face-to-face education. However, 2nd and 3rd stage of secondary education is 50% face-to-face education. For higher education, only 1 day/week can be physically on campus. 
Exams can be taken in person. Indoor day trips will be permitted. Face masks for those in the fifth and sixth years of primary are still required. Interaction between classes is advised to be as limited as possible.
Depending on the covid situation at the time, 2nd and 3rd stage of secondary can more to 100% face-to-face education May 3rd.

description:
Belgium: As per the summer four-step plan, in the first step to be in place on June 9th, catering and parties and major events can restart. 
The catering industry will reopen indoors between 8am and 10pm. The maximum number of people per table is 4 or one household per table. A distance of least 1.5 meters must be maintained between tables. 
Outdoor catering establishments will be able to remain open until 11.30pm instead of 10pm. The table rules will remain the same: 4 people or one household per table and a distance of 1.5 meters between tables. Parties and receptions: up to 50 people indoors. For the remainder, they must follow the rules for the catering industry.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: Belgium: As of the 26th of April, restaurants are allowed to reopen and gatherings of 10 people are permitted. However, conditions for terraces have been put in place by the Consultative Committee. A maximum of 4 people, or one household, are allowed at one table. There must be at least 1.5 meters between tables. Face masks are mandatory for staff and any non-seated customers. You can not order directly from the bar, there is only table seating. Customers can only go inside briefly to use the washroom, pay, or reach the terrace. Opening hours are limited to 8am till 10pm.

description:
Belgium requires students in more regions to wear masks in 
classes. New rules entered into force on Monday in Belgium that oblige students to wear facial masks in schools of Wallonia and Flanders regions as part of measures against the coronavirus.
Students of 5th and 6th grades in Flemish primary schools, as well as secondary school students in Wallonia, must wear facial masks during classes as of Monday after regional authorities imposed in October new rules to stem the spread of COVID-19.Flemish secondary schoolers can still attend the classes without covering their noses and mouths because the vaccination rate for the age group of 12-18 is high in the region. 
Date: 11.08.2021
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside Secondary Schools (generally for children ages 10 to 18)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
New rules entered into force on Monday in Belgium that oblige students to wear facial masks in schools of Wallonia and Flanders regions as part of measures against the coronavirus.

Students of 5th and 6th grades in Flemish primary schools, as well as secondary school students in Wallonia, must wear facial masks during classes as of Monday after regional authorities imposed in October new rules to stem the spread of COVID-19.

The government of the Flanders region decided on Oct. 27 to make masks obligatory in the last two grades of primary schools after a speedy rise of infections.

Flemish secondary schoolers can still attend the classes without covering their noses and mouths because the vaccination rate for the age group of 12-18 is high in the region.

Also, Wallonian high school students have to wear masks during classes, while primary school students can stay in the classroom without masks.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside Secondary Schools (generally for children ages 10 to 18)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
New rules entered into force on Monday in Belgium that oblige students to wear facial masks in schools of Wallonia and Flanders regions as part of measures against the coronavirus.

Students of 5th and 6th grades in Flemish primary schools, as well as secondary school students in Wallonia, must wear facial masks during classes as of Monday after regional authorities imposed in October new rules to stem the spread of COVID-19.

The government of the Flanders region decided on Oct. 27 to make masks obligatory in the last two grades of primary schools after a speedy rise of infections.

Flemish secondary schoolers can still attend the classes without covering their noses and mouths because the vaccination rate for the age group of 12-18 is high in the region.

Also, Wallonian high school students have to wear masks during classes, while primary school students can stay in the classroom without masks. UPDATE: Tuesday, August 17, 2021  Regulations on the wearing of masks in schools have been relaxed in Wallonia, education ministers confirmed on Tuesday.Staff working in educational institutions in Wallonia, will now no longer have to wear masks when moving around the institutions. Pupils will still be required to wear masks outside if social distancing cannot be respected.
